instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the batteryâ€™s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Liquid damage around <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR>.

Damaged components replaced. Traces are OK,

No chime.
20V on charger and it take 2.2A short but fast fan spin and reboot.
Trackpad clicks, caps lock LED not working.

Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> level.
Try starting in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 1.04V

No luck with SMC bypass mode - only sign of life is trackpad .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage is stable?
AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> got 12.6V but there is drop to around 10V during that short fan spin and then again stable 12.6V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2V and when fan spin drop to 0V and then back to 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V and when fan spin drop to 0V and then back to 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> present
P1V1SLPS2R_SW0 present
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Is the battery charing?
Try to start with battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Is the battery charing?
Try to start with battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
I connected battery and got 20.1V and 0.06A from charger which is around 1.2W.

After 15 minutes USB C meter shows there was 14mAh "used"

<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> have a few second 12.6V and then a few seconds 0.16V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Does the board try to start when battery is connected?
Try using SWK000/2 pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Trackpad click, but no short fan spin.

No luck with SWK000/2 pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
Trackpad click is irrelevant.
Is an hardware response, once its coils are energized.
Do not consider the click as life sign.

I was expecting you will check for reaction on S5 voltages, or S4 signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message:
"Do not consider the click as life sign." - thank you , will remember that
           
       
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> - 5.13V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_T_USBC</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL> - 0V                                   

Will that help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> quarter fan spin?
threads.message: With battery connected (and charger), check for reaction at <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (at same time) when trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; use SWK000/2 pads.
